transformed_texts:
The Church. It has its ways. Old ways. The men in robes talk of dwindling numbers. A harvest failing. I reckon it's these things they hold tight to, these rigid stances. Marriage, the taking of life, the control of the body. They speak of sin and damnation. But the world, it turns. Times change.

Folks don't bend so easy anymore. There's a restlessness out there, a hunger for something more. They see the Church, and they see a shadow. A darkness clinging to the corners of faith.

They say the Church is against abortion, against the joining of two souls in love, against the choices a woman makes. And some, they hear these words and walk away. They seek a different kind of sanctuary, one that doesn't judge, that doesn't condemn. 

A woman, a priestess, perhaps. A man, bound by vows but not to God alone.  These are the whispers in the wind. Could it have changed things? Maybe. But the darkness, it finds a way.

The matter of marriage.  A man and a woman. Two men. Two women.  Seems a simple enough thing, wouldn't you say? But the world, it twists and turns.  Some folks born a certain way. Some not. Doesn't make 'em any less...human.  To deny them the right, to call it wrong.  Seems a hard thing to stomach. Not my place to judge, not my choice to make. The government, they meddle in things they don't understand. This ain't a question of law, ain't no law against love, against the way folks feel.  It's about right and wrong.  And that's a question for the heart, not for some suit in Washington.

The matter of marriage, of two souls bound, is a thing the law should not hold in thrall. Some speak of threats, of the family structure warped by love between men or women. But what threat is there in devotion? In a world where shadows lengthen, where kinship is not always blood, is a love less true for lacking the shape prescribed?

The coin has two sides, yes. But it is the metal that matters, the heart that beats beneath. The law should not be a judge of the heart. There are rights, rights that bind, rights that shelter in sickness and in health. A partner denied, a hand held back, is a wound the law should not inflict.

And the studies whisper, a chorus of voices, that love finds its form in many ways. Happiness blooms in fields of every hue, in gardens cultivated by hands of different shapes.

The church, a house of faith, should not hold dominion over the state. Let the state provide shelter, let it not dictate the shape of love.

Some cling to ancient fears, to scriptures turned to iron bars. They speak of morality, of a path predestined. But morality is a shifting thing, a compass guided by the heart.

To deny a love, a bond forged in the fires of devotion, is to deny a part of the human story. It is to build walls where bridges should stand.  

It is in the embracing of difference, in the recognition of a love that knows no bounds, that we find the truest measure of humanity.

The pharmacy. Summer work. You see these pills, these poisons, stacked high behind glass.  Just because a thing is outlawed doesn't mean it holds no use.  No, sir.  There's a line.  For the open market, no.  But for healing?  Yes.  Medicinal, maybe.  Just because it's dirty doesn't mean it ain't got its uses.  

Think of the ones they keep locked tight, the oxycotins, the vicodins, the percocets.  Controlled, they call 'em.  But we dispense 'em daily.  For good, for bad.  Same with this weed. This marijuana.  They call it devil's lettuce, but it might just hold the key.  

Alcohol.  That's a different beast.  You can drown yourself in it, mind and body.  But this, this herb, it's different.  It ain't a demon, not like the hard stuff.  

Maybe a slow hand on the throttle.  Legalize it, yes, but not in a rush.  Let 'em get used to it, let the shame fade.  Then maybe, just maybe, they'll use it right.  

See, the fear they have... it's all made up.  They tell you it's poison, but it ain't heroin, ain't cocaine.  It's just a plant.  If you treat it with respect, maybe it'll give you back some.

The church, it’s changed. Like the wind shifts, it’s taken on a new shape. Not as stiff as it once was. I remember Sundays when I was a girl. Dresses all buttoned and laced. Shoes to match, a purse to match. Every Sunday, the ritual. Same as all the other girls. Private school, the whole lot of us, dressed up like dolls for mass. But now, it’s different. They’ve got a mass for the young ones, quick and sharp, thirty minutes gone in the blink of an eye. People come in their beach clothes, sand still clinging to their toes. Families rushing in late, children crying. Jeans and khakis now at the morning masses, where I used to stand stiff as a board in my Sunday best. 

The politics of it all, I don’t know much about that. But the change, I see it. That’s the church I know now.   

The talk, the accusations against the priests.  Evil things. I don’t know if any change could have stopped it. There are married men, good men, who do bad things. It’s a sickness, a darkness inside. Like a storm cloud gathering. It don't matter if they’re married or not.

They choose to be priests. It’s a path they walk. Some churches, they let the priests marry.  Like on that show, “Seventh Heaven.” The preacher, he had a wife, had children. But for those who choose the priesthood, maybe it’s not the right path. Maybe they should find a different way to serve.

This whole thing, it’s in their blood. It’s in their genes, I think.  Like a sickness passed down. Can’t hide it with a wedding ring.  It’d come out anyway.

If they knew and covered it up, shame on them. But maybe, in some cases, they didn’t know.

The laughter caught in his throat, a dry rasp. He'd tried to swallow it down, but the air itself felt thick with it. At first, he'd been okay, he supposed. But the day, that day, the world had tilted.  September's shadow had fallen long and heavy. And they went in, into that dust-filled land, under a guise, a pretense.  The Bush men, they'd tied it all together, the war, the towers, Bin Laden's shadow, Hussein's phantom weapons. A lie, all of it, a tapestry woven from smoke and fear.  It had chafed him, this deceit, this blood spilled in the name of a phantom enemy.  The Bush men, they'd lied to the people, plain and simple. Even Powell, the man who'd stood before the world and spun their tale, now admitted to doubt.  Malfeasance. An offense against the very heart of the nation.  

He saw it all, the slow erosion of the Constitution, the creeping darkness since the towers fell.  They'd come in, these men, with war in their eyes, a hunger for vengeance.  He recalled the name, a fleeting whisper, the treasury man who'd spoken truth, driven out like a dog.  The younger Bush, he'd carried the weight of his father's shadow, a thirst for retribution.  And oil. Always oil, the black blood whispering promises of power.

It had dragged on, this war, this wound festering in the land. A withdrawal, a sudden pullback, would only leave a bleeding corpse.  The UN, they'd spoken of a new order, a coalition, a patchwork of nations from the desert. But what guarantee was there?  Would Iraq's sovereignty be a hollow shell, a name whispered on the wind?

He saw the whispers, the news reports, the crumbling Parliament, the Prime Minister, a king without a kingdom.  Sadr, the man they'd fought, his name a ghost in the halls of power.  Factions, each clawing for control, each hungry for the spoils.  Friction, a slow burn, threatening to ignite the tinderbox. 

The laughter came again, this time a choked sound, swallowed back down. Words, they failed him.  There were things, truths, he couldn't speak, not in this light.

The air hung thick, hot.  The questions, they came like cicadas, buzzing in his ear.  Iraq. The word tasted like dust and ashes in his mouth.  A pointless thing, he thought. A reckoning, a score to settle.  But for what?  Ghosts of towers falling, a shadow cast across the world.  Nine-eleven.  A wound that wouldn't heal, festering.  He wasn't a soldier, never had been.  Didn't know the names of the battles, the faces of the lost.  Just knew the weight of it, the hollowness.  

Democracy, they said.  A seed planted in barren soil.  Oil, the black blood of the earth, a thirst that never quenched.  He saw the anger, the broken lives, the endless cycle of violence.  A land carved up, a people torn.  

To leave, to stay – both paths choked with thorns.  To fight, to build, to hold on.  The ghosts of Vietnam whispered in his ear, a warning.  A war without end, a stain on the nation's soul.  

He thought of the boys, the girls, the faces of the young, sent into the furnace.  And the families waiting, holding their breath, their hearts cracking.  He thought of the children, robbed of their laughter, their innocence.  A world drowned in blood, a future uncertain.  

The weight of it all, a burden too heavy to bear.  The war in Iraq, a tangled knot of shadows and lies.  No easy answers, only the echo of gunfire, the whisper of the wind through the ruins.

The law, it ain't right. No state should lay claim to it. This ain't their business. The Bible it speaks. Church and state. Divided. Plain as day. You try to force it, to twist it to your will, you're spitting in the face of what's already carved in stone.  The ones pushing it down, they're picking and choosing.  Favor one flock over another. The Catholics, most of 'em stand against it.  The Christians too.  Except up in Boston, maybe a few outposts. But the government, they got no right to tell the churches what they can and can't preach.  Separation. That's the heart of it.  Tolerance.  

To amend the thing, that's just wrong. A contradiction. The only amendment I can think of that would chain the people, not the government.

This ain't the government's fight.  This ain't about the economy or the streets. It's about faith, about personal convictions. The man pushing this, he's just trying to impose his own beliefs on the rest of us. One religion over all the others.

It belongs to the churches. It belongs to the people. Not the president, not the politicians.

The war. A long shadow. Iraq.  Didn't the government tell us the truth? About why they went in, why they claimed the desert was a battlefield.  A tangled web they spun, linking it to that September day, the smoke rising. But the desert held a different truth. A truth born of sand and blood. 

I've never been one for war.  Especially not this kind. A strike in the dark, preemptive. A gambler's bet with lives. Like Vietnam, a mirror held up, reflecting the ghosts of a past we refused to learn from. How many sons and daughters laid low, their dreams turned to dust?  And for what? To carve out a new order, to impose a government on a land that had a government of its own?  

They said they'd bring democracy. Like seeds sown in fertile ground. But the land was arid, its people hardened.  They fought not an army, but a spirit, a resistance born of grief and fear.  We thought it would be quick. A swift victory, a clean sweep.  But the desert doesn't yield easily. It swallows promises and spits out despair.

We've been there years now, still trying to mold the land to our will. Still teaching them to police themselves, to be the government we want them to be.  A long and bloody lesson, etched in the sand.  

Maybe we should have stayed away. Maybe we should have learned from the ghosts of Vietnam.  Maybe the truth wasn't hidden in the desert, but staring back at us from the mirror. A mirror reflecting our own hubris, our own thirst for dominion.

The boy spoke slow, drawling out the words like a hawk scanning the plains. "I'm for it," he said, "always have been." He squinted, as if the sun was too bright, or maybe he was just thinking hard. "A man loves a man, a woman a woman. It's a thing of the blood, not of the mind. To take that away, to deny them a name, a place at the table... that's a sin. It's inhuman." His voice dropped to a whisper. "My own street, there's a couple, two men, never married. They walk their dogs, like any other folks. They love each other. It's no different. But they can't say it, can't claim it." He spit on the ground. "That man in Washington, trying to play God, twisting the words of love... it's a mockery."

He paused, his eyes distant. "They say now, it's in the brain,  chemistry. Some things you're born with, can't help it. Like the sky, the rain, the pull of the earth." He sighed. "It ain't like a boy growing up with sisters, yearning for a brother. That ain't it." He shook his head. "It's a simple thing, love. Two people wanting to stay together, to build a life. Should be their own business, not the government's." 

He looked away, his voice a low rumble. "A man and a woman, they can run off, get hitched in Vegas. Nobody cares. But two men, two women... that's news. A scandal. It's wrong." He spat again, the sound sharp and metallic. "Love should be private, not a spectacle. It's not theirs to control."

The net. A public square. That's what they say. And it's true enough. You spit something out there, it hangs in the air. Colors folks' minds.  Might be harmless enough, a joke maybe. Or it might be a whisper of fire.  

Seen it myself.  As a resident advisor, you see the undercurrents.  A kid posts some talk about blowin' things up, about violence, and the whispers start. Someone's gotta hear it. Someone's gotta act.  They can't just let it float, can they? What if it takes root? What if it blossoms? 

But the line's blurry, ain't it?  Sometimes it's just kids, messing around.  A sociology project gone wrong, maybe. A bad joke, meant to be funny, but landing heavy as a tombstone.  

Then there are the times when it's not a joke.  A seed of darkness, planted in the fertile ground of the net.  A boy, a friend, something he posted. A dark joke, maybe. But in the right light, it looked like a threat. 

The school found out. Had to. It's a tightrope walk, between freedom and fear.  You put it out there, it's out there.  No privacy in the net.

The war. It stretches on. A wound that won't close. At first, it had a purpose, they said. Democracy for a land choked by tyrants. But the purpose, like the desert wind, has shifted. Now it's something else. A show of force. A hunger to prove dominion. Maybe the hunger was there all along. Bush the elder and his grudges with the desert fox. A serpent's coil tightening around a nation.  

If the aim had been to bring light to the darkness, to lift the weight of tyranny, that would have been a cause worthy of steel and blood. But if it was fueled by personal debts, by ghosts of battles past, then it was a sickness from the start.

The first strike, it spoke volumes. A thunderclap in the stillness. But the echo lingers. Years bleed into years. The desert sands turn red. And for what? We are the hammer, they say, but the anvil has moved too far.

A country cannot be built on the bones of men, nor on the spilled blood of boys. A nation doesn't find its voice in the roar of guns. 

There are things to be done here, at home. A rot in the bones of our own land. Poverty, hunger, the slow decay of dreams. These are the battles that demand our attention. 

The money, the endless money, it's a river flowing into a bottomless pit. A pit built of sand and dust, of promises broken and lives extinguished. 

The time has come to turn away. To close the book on this chapter. To let the desert reclaim its own. The sons of that land must learn to fend for themselves. They must find their own path. 

It's time to walk away.

The question hung there, a fly caught in the amber of the air.  Someone, it seemed, had gone searching, peering into the digital dark. Found something.  Stopped it.  Was it wrong?  This invasion, this looking.  

On these Myspace things, you put things out there.  Information.  Open.  Like a town square, everyone walks by.  Friend or stranger, it's all the same.  You've given them leave to see, to read.   

But what if you're looking for something else?  Not just any profile.  Looking for the signs, the whispers, the darkness brewing beneath the surface.  One man watching them all.  The good and the bad.  Seems wrong somehow.  A violation.  But what if it saves a life?

It's a hard thing.  A thin line.  Information out there, open to the taking.  Like a river flowing, you can't dam it up.  But you can try to watch the currents, to know where the danger might lie.

I see it myself, the creeping shadows.  People looking in, knowing things they shouldn't.  My own picture, my words, my life, laid bare.  A man on TV, a ghoul.  He showed how easy it was.  Found a girl's name, her screen, her world.  Talked to her, tricked her, all in a whisper.  He knew her secrets before she even knew what was coming.

It's a strange feeling, this knowing.  That someone out there, a stranger, knows you better than you know yourself.  Your likes, your fears, your hopes.  It's a violation, a theft.

But it's also a part of this world now.  The internet, a vast and sprawling thing.  A place where secrets are whispered and shared, where the lines between public and private blur. 

The school, they tried to stop it.  Myspace banned.  A line drawn in the sand.  But can you really stop the flow?  Can you hold back the tide?

The desert wind scoured the edges of thought. This war. A stain on the sand. A bad idea from the start, they said. And they were right. The world knew it. Even those who wore the uniform, the ones sent to sift the sand for hope, knew it. A silent understanding in the eyes, a weariness in the heart. The polls, they spoke their truth.  Seventy-five percent, eighty percent. A chorus of dissent rising from the earth itself.  The Iraqi dust, the smoke of burning oil, the ghosts of a shattered land. It clung to the air, a constant reminder of the folly. Democracy, they said, a seed sown in barren ground. A fragile thing, crushed beneath the weight of history.  Saddam, a tyrant, yes. But what good is a fallen king if his kingdom crumbles to dust?  The desert waits, patient and unforgiving. It swallows the past, the present, the future. What good is staying? What hope is there in the wasteland?

The world, it ain't changed much. Not for women, anyway.  The glass ceiling, they call it.  Still there, though it's supposed to be shattered. Men, they got trouble seeing a woman at the head of the table. Like it ain't natural. Ain't right.  But you see it in every damn field.  

Take a woman with the know-how, the qualifications, she's ready to climb. But the men at the top, they don't take her serious. They see a woman, they think weakness. History, it's a heavy thing, drags us down.

Same for the men.  Tried to raise a child, stay home with the little ones?  They get the stink eye.  Society expects the man to be the provider, the breadwinner.  But what about the man who wants to nurture?  To hold his child, teach him, raise him?  He gets judged.  

And in those fancy places, the fashion world, the men who love it, they get looked at funny.  Don't belong there, they say.  Too feminine. Like a man can't know beauty, can't understand style.  

It's a twisted thing, this world we live in.  Change is slow, gradual like the setting sun. We're getting there, though.  More women in the boardrooms, more men at home with the kids.  It's a fight, but we're fighting.

They didn’t make it legal, no. Decriminalized it.  Knocked it down from a crime to a ticket.  Something you get cited for, not booked, not hauled in.  Still, the shadow of the charge, it lingers. Job interviews, all those things.  The weight of it, even with the label changed. 

Kids worry about that. The future, the mark it leaves.  But the state, they spend a fortune catching, holding, charging.  A court appearance here, maybe two, three.  Public defenders, judges, the whole apparatus.  And for what?  A lot of municipalities, strapped for coin, they can’t afford to let go of that revenue.  Even if it frees up funds for schools, for the elderly, for the hungry.

Denver’s different.  People there, they lean a different way.  Liberal, they call it.  More open.  And so maybe there, it makes sense.  The money saved, it can go elsewhere.

But to legalize it, to sell it like cigarettes,  that’s a different matter.  Everywhere, smoke curling from cars, from mouths on every street corner.  It wouldn’t feel right.  There’s a stigma, a taboo, that wouldn’t disappear that easy.

Alcohol, it’s worse for your hands, maybe.  But weed, it twists your life, your habits.  Both bad in their own ways.  But people, they react different.  Some go wild, some find balance.  It’s hard to say.

The Church. A house of stone and shadow. They say tradition is a root, that it holds you firm. But roots can strangle, too. They cling to the old ways, the dust on the altars, the pronouncements from long dead men. And they judge. They judge the straying sheep, the ones who don't fit the fold. My mother, she walked a different path. Episcopalian. They wouldn't let them in the church.  She loved God, but they wouldn't have her.  Love them, they preach. But this love is a cage, a gilded cage, for the chosen few. They speak of grace, but they offer only judgment.  

They say priests should be above it all,  above the weight of the flesh. But the flesh is a heavy thing.  It yearns. It betrays. And in the dark, behind closed doors, the sanctity of the cloth can’t hold back the shadows.  A man’s hunger, it knows no commandments.  They say marriage would be a distraction, but the heart seeks connection, even in the darkest of places. Is it the cloth that corrupts, or the man beneath? 

I don’t know.  I only know the stain of hypocrisy, the smell of incense masking the stench of rot.

The matter hangs heavy. No easy answers there. Right and wrong, a blurred line in the dust. This thing, the church and the state, tangled up with the very definition of a bond. A line walked on eggshells, lest we offend some corner of the world.  

Civil unions, maybe. A simple joining. Two souls. The government, should it concern itself with the particulars of such a thing?  Baptized souls, they walk unseen by the ledger of the state. The same should hold true for those bound in marriage. A sacrament, a joining of hearts, not a legal instrument to be weighed and measured.

But if the states can find common ground, a logic to the matter, then let it rise, a federal law.  But to amend the Constitution, to ban this love, this union, that is a folly. The Constitution, a heavy thing, not to be tampered with for matters of fleeting passions. Let them live their lives, these souls bound by love. Leave the Constitution to rest.

Raised in the fold. Christian. The word hangs, a shadow, over these matters.  Sexuality, a tangled vine, twisting in the light. Friends, some of them drawn towards the dark, the unspoken.  I don't know that I could walk that path myself. But the law, that's a different thing.  A heavy hand, reaching too far, dictating the lives of men.  The whole country, bound by a single decree?  No.  Let the states decide.  Let the people of each land choose their own way.  Some states lean left, some right.  The tide turns, the wind shifts.  Let them grapple with these questions, these choices.  A man can't choose his own home, but he can choose to abide by its laws.  Give them the same chance.  Equal footing.  Same as the rest.  Let the states decide.  And let the president, that distant hand, stay out of it. His power, it doesn't reach to every corner.

The boy spoke slow.  His words hung heavy in the air, like smoke from some long-dead fire. "It's public," he said. "Like a bulletin board. If you put something out there, you gotta figure folks'll see it.  School folks too."  He paused, fiddling with a loose thread on his shirt. 

"They weren't using the school's name or nothin'," he continued, "but they coulda found it. From their own homes.  Maybe it's wrong, maybe it ain't.  But if it stops some kid from gettin' hurt, well, that's a good thing, ain't it?  That's what schools are for. Keepin' folks safe."

He chewed on his lip, eyes fixed on the floor. "You know, it's easier to say what you mean when you're writin'.  But when you're talkin', words get tangled up, like weeds in a ditch." He looked up, his gaze direct. "Like I said, it's public. If you don't want folks seein' what you're sayin', you keep it to yourself."

He recalled a teacher, a woman with tired eyes and a voice worn thin from years of talkin' to kids. "She said, 'We gotta be safe,' she said. 'We gotta be ready for anything.'" He remembered the drills, the cold metal of the fire escape, the way the world seemed to shrink down to the size of that classroom. "We practiced, just in case.  Didn't want to be caught off guard."

He sighed, the weight of it all settling on his shoulders.  "That's what they were doin', I reckon. Just tryin' to keep folks safe. From somethin' bad."

The war. A fevered thing. Nine eleven. It burned in ya. Made ya want to answer back.  Like fire for fire.  Go over there and make them feel what we felt.  But maybe that was the sickness. All that heat. Didn't leave room for thinking.  No time for plans. Just fire. And it backfired.  It always does.

They fight amongst themselves.  Cannibal country.  Us going in there, it don't matter. They'll tear each other apart anyway. Doesn't change a thing.  I used to care, I guess. About what went on over there. Now it's just a weariness. A dull ache. Don't know if they're human anymore.  Just shadows with hatred in their eyes.

We went in blind. Didn't know what we faced. They fight different.  Savages.  Not building, not mending. Just tearing.  They want us gone. And maybe that's the only thing they're right about.  We shouldn't be there. Just hype.  Revenge.  Bush, he wanted it too. They wanted it. A voice in the dark saying "go." And we went.  

No thought. No plan. Just the echo of the fire.

transformed_texts:
The Church. It has its ways. Old ways. The men in robes talk of dwindling numbers. A harvest failing. I reckon it's these things they hold tight to, these rigid stances. Marriage, the taking of life, the control of the body. They speak of sin and damnation. But the world, it turns. Times change.

Folks don't bend so easy anymore. There's a restlessness out there, a hunger for something more. They see the Church, and they see a shadow. A darkness clinging to the corners of faith.

They say the Church is against abortion, against the joining of two souls in love, against the choices a woman makes. And some, they hear these words and walk away. They seek a different kind of sanctuary, one that doesn't judge, that doesn't condemn. 

A woman, a priestess, perhaps. A man, bound by vows but not to God alone.  These are the whispers in the wind. Could it have changed things? Maybe. But the darkness, it finds a way.

The matter of marriage.  A man and a woman. Two men. Two women.  Seems a simple enough thing, wouldn't you say? But the world, it twists and turns.  Some folks born a certain way. Some not. Doesn't make 'em any less...human.  To deny them the right, to call it wrong.  Seems a hard thing to stomach. Not my place to judge, not my choice to make. The government, they meddle in things they don't understand. This ain't a question of law, ain't no law against love, against the way folks feel.  It's about right and wrong.  And that's a question for the heart, not for some suit in Washington.

The matter of marriage, of two souls bound, is a thing the law should not hold in thrall. Some speak of threats, of the family structure warped by love between men or women. But what threat is there in devotion? In a world where shadows lengthen, where kinship is not always blood, is a love less true for lacking the shape prescribed?

The coin has two sides, yes. But it is the metal that matters, the heart that beats beneath. The law should not be a judge of the heart. There are rights, rights that bind, rights that shelter in sickness and in health. A partner denied, a hand held back, is a wound the law should not inflict.

And the studies whisper, a chorus of voices, that love finds its form in many ways. Happiness blooms in fields of every hue, in gardens cultivated by hands of different shapes.

The church, a house of faith, should not hold dominion over the state. Let the state provide shelter, let it not dictate the shape of love.

Some cling to ancient fears, to scriptures turned to iron bars. They speak of morality, of a path predestined. But morality is a shifting thing, a compass guided by the heart.

To deny a love, a bond forged in the fires of devotion, is to deny a part of the human story. It is to build walls where bridges should stand.  

It is in the embracing of difference, in the recognition of a love that knows no bounds, that we find the truest measure of humanity.

The pharmacy. Summer work. You see these pills, these poisons, stacked high behind glass.  Just because a thing is outlawed doesn't mean it holds no use.  No, sir.  There's a line.  For the open market, no.  But for healing?  Yes.  Medicinal, maybe.  Just because it's dirty doesn't mean it ain't got its uses.  

Think of the ones they keep locked tight, the oxycotins, the vicodins, the percocets.  Controlled, they call 'em.  But we dispense 'em daily.  For good, for bad.  Same with this weed. This marijuana.  They call it devil's lettuce, but it might just hold the key.  

Alcohol.  That's a different beast.  You can drown yourself in it, mind and body.  But this, this herb, it's different.  It ain't a demon, not like the hard stuff.  

Maybe a slow hand on the throttle.  Legalize it, yes, but not in a rush.  Let 'em get used to it, let the shame fade.  Then maybe, just maybe, they'll use it right.  

See, the fear they have... it's all made up.  They tell you it's poison, but it ain't heroin, ain't cocaine.  It's just a plant.  If you treat it with respect, maybe it'll give you back some.

The church, it’s changed. Like the wind shifts, it’s taken on a new shape. Not as stiff as it once was. I remember Sundays when I was a girl. Dresses all buttoned and laced. Shoes to match, a purse to match. Every Sunday, the ritual. Same as all the other girls. Private school, the whole lot of us, dressed up like dolls for mass. But now, it’s different. They’ve got a mass for the young ones, quick and sharp, thirty minutes gone in the blink of an eye. People come in their beach clothes, sand still clinging to their toes. Families rushing in late, children crying. Jeans and khakis now at the morning masses, where I used to stand stiff as a board in my Sunday best. 

The politics of it all, I don’t know much about that. But the change, I see it. That’s the church I know now.   

The talk, the accusations against the priests.  Evil things. I don’t know if any change could have stopped it. There are married men, good men, who do bad things. It’s a sickness, a darkness inside. Like a storm cloud gathering. It don't matter if they’re married or not.

They choose to be priests. It’s a path they walk. Some churches, they let the priests marry.  Like on that show, “Seventh Heaven.” The preacher, he had a wife, had children. But for those who choose the priesthood, maybe it’s not the right path. Maybe they should find a different way to serve.

This whole thing, it’s in their blood. It’s in their genes, I think.  Like a sickness passed down. Can’t hide it with a wedding ring.  It’d come out anyway.

If they knew and covered it up, shame on them. But maybe, in some cases, they didn’t know.

The laughter caught in his throat, a dry rasp. He'd tried to swallow it down, but the air itself felt thick with it. At first, he'd been okay, he supposed. But the day, that day, the world had tilted.  September's shadow had fallen long and heavy. And they went in, into that dust-filled land, under a guise, a pretense.  The Bush men, they'd tied it all together, the war, the towers, Bin Laden's shadow, Hussein's phantom weapons. A lie, all of it, a tapestry woven from smoke and fear.  It had chafed him, this deceit, this blood spilled in the name of a phantom enemy.  The Bush men, they'd lied to the people, plain and simple. Even Powell, the man who'd stood before the world and spun their tale, now admitted to doubt.  Malfeasance. An offense against the very heart of the nation.  

He saw it all, the slow erosion of the Constitution, the creeping darkness since the towers fell.  They'd come in, these men, with war in their eyes, a hunger for vengeance.  He recalled the name, a fleeting whisper, the treasury man who'd spoken truth, driven out like a dog.  The younger Bush, he'd carried the weight of his father's shadow, a thirst for retribution.  And oil. Always oil, the black blood whispering promises of power.

It had dragged on, this war, this wound festering in the land. A withdrawal, a sudden pullback, would only leave a bleeding corpse.  The UN, they'd spoken of a new order, a coalition, a patchwork of nations from the desert. But what guarantee was there?  Would Iraq's sovereignty be a hollow shell, a name whispered on the wind?

He saw the whispers, the news reports, the crumbling Parliament, the Prime Minister, a king without a kingdom.  Sadr, the man they'd fought, his name a ghost in the halls of power.  Factions, each clawing for control, each hungry for the spoils.  Friction, a slow burn, threatening to ignite the tinderbox. 

The laughter came again, this time a choked sound, swallowed back down. Words, they failed him.  There were things, truths, he couldn't speak, not in this light.

The air hung thick, hot.  The questions, they came like cicadas, buzzing in his ear.  Iraq. The word tasted like dust and ashes in his mouth.  A pointless thing, he thought. A reckoning, a score to settle.  But for what?  Ghosts of towers falling, a shadow cast across the world.  Nine-eleven.  A wound that wouldn't heal, festering.  He wasn't a soldier, never had been.  Didn't know the names of the battles, the faces of the lost.  Just knew the weight of it, the hollowness.  

Democracy, they said.  A seed planted in barren soil.  Oil, the black blood of the earth, a thirst that never quenched.  He saw the anger, the broken lives, the endless cycle of violence.  A land carved up, a people torn.  

To leave, to stay – both paths choked with thorns.  To fight, to build, to hold on.  The ghosts of Vietnam whispered in his ear, a warning.  A war without end, a stain on the nation's soul.  

He thought of the boys, the girls, the faces of the young, sent into the furnace.  And the families waiting, holding their breath, their hearts cracking.  He thought of the children, robbed of their laughter, their innocence.  A world drowned in blood, a future uncertain.  

The weight of it all, a burden too heavy to bear.  The war in Iraq, a tangled knot of shadows and lies.  No easy answers, only the echo of gunfire, the whisper of the wind through the ruins.

The law, it ain't right. No state should lay claim to it. This ain't their business. The Bible it speaks. Church and state. Divided. Plain as day. You try to force it, to twist it to your will, you're spitting in the face of what's already carved in stone.  The ones pushing it down, they're picking and choosing.  Favor one flock over another. The Catholics, most of 'em stand against it.  The Christians too.  Except up in Boston, maybe a few outposts. But the government, they got no right to tell the churches what they can and can't preach.  Separation. That's the heart of it.  Tolerance.  

To amend the thing, that's just wrong. A contradiction. The only amendment I can think of that would chain the people, not the government.

This ain't the government's fight.  This ain't about the economy or the streets. It's about faith, about personal convictions. The man pushing this, he's just trying to impose his own beliefs on the rest of us. One religion over all the others.

It belongs to the churches. It belongs to the people. Not the president, not the politicians.

The war. A long shadow. Iraq.  Didn't the government tell us the truth? About why they went in, why they claimed the desert was a battlefield.  A tangled web they spun, linking it to that September day, the smoke rising. But the desert held a different truth. A truth born of sand and blood. 

I've never been one for war.  Especially not this kind. A strike in the dark, preemptive. A gambler's bet with lives. Like Vietnam, a mirror held up, reflecting the ghosts of a past we refused to learn from. How many sons and daughters laid low, their dreams turned to dust?  And for what? To carve out a new order, to impose a government on a land that had a government of its own?  

They said they'd bring democracy. Like seeds sown in fertile ground. But the land was arid, its people hardened.  They fought not an army, but a spirit, a resistance born of grief and fear.  We thought it would be quick. A swift victory, a clean sweep.  But the desert doesn't yield easily. It swallows promises and spits out despair.

We've been there years now, still trying to mold the land to our will. Still teaching them to police themselves, to be the government we want them to be.  A long and bloody lesson, etched in the sand.  

Maybe we should have stayed away. Maybe we should have learned from the ghosts of Vietnam.  Maybe the truth wasn't hidden in the desert, but staring back at us from the mirror. A mirror reflecting our own hubris, our own thirst for dominion.

The boy spoke slow, drawling out the words like a hawk scanning the plains. "I'm for it," he said, "always have been." He squinted, as if the sun was too bright, or maybe he was just thinking hard. "A man loves a man, a woman a woman. It's a thing of the blood, not of the mind. To take that away, to deny them a name, a place at the table... that's a sin. It's inhuman." His voice dropped to a whisper. "My own street, there's a couple, two men, never married. They walk their dogs, like any other folks. They love each other. It's no different. But they can't say it, can't claim it." He spit on the ground. "That man in Washington, trying to play God, twisting the words of love... it's a mockery."

He paused, his eyes distant. "They say now, it's in the brain,  chemistry. Some things you're born with, can't help it. Like the sky, the rain, the pull of the earth." He sighed. "It ain't like a boy growing up with sisters, yearning for a brother. That ain't it." He shook his head. "It's a simple thing, love. Two people wanting to stay together, to build a life. Should be their own business, not the government's." 

He looked away, his voice a low rumble. "A man and a woman, they can run off, get hitched in Vegas. Nobody cares. But two men, two women... that's news. A scandal. It's wrong." He spat again, the sound sharp and metallic. "Love should be private, not a spectacle. It's not theirs to control."

The net. A public square. That's what they say. And it's true enough. You spit something out there, it hangs in the air. Colors folks' minds.  Might be harmless enough, a joke maybe. Or it might be a whisper of fire.  

Seen it myself.  As a resident advisor, you see the undercurrents.  A kid posts some talk about blowin' things up, about violence, and the whispers start. Someone's gotta hear it. Someone's gotta act.  They can't just let it float, can they? What if it takes root? What if it blossoms? 

But the line's blurry, ain't it?  Sometimes it's just kids, messing around.  A sociology project gone wrong, maybe. A bad joke, meant to be funny, but landing heavy as a tombstone.  

Then there are the times when it's not a joke.  A seed of darkness, planted in the fertile ground of the net.  A boy, a friend, something he posted. A dark joke, maybe. But in the right light, it looked like a threat. 

The school found out. Had to. It's a tightrope walk, between freedom and fear.  You put it out there, it's out there.  No privacy in the net.

The war. It stretches on. A wound that won't close. At first, it had a purpose, they said. Democracy for a land choked by tyrants. But the purpose, like the desert wind, has shifted. Now it's something else. A show of force. A hunger to prove dominion. Maybe the hunger was there all along. Bush the elder and his grudges with the desert fox. A serpent's coil tightening around a nation.  

If the aim had been to bring light to the darkness, to lift the weight of tyranny, that would have been a cause worthy of steel and blood. But if it was fueled by personal debts, by ghosts of battles past, then it was a sickness from the start.

The first strike, it spoke volumes. A thunderclap in the stillness. But the echo lingers. Years bleed into years. The desert sands turn red. And for what? We are the hammer, they say, but the anvil has moved too far.

A country cannot be built on the bones of men, nor on the spilled blood of boys. A nation doesn't find its voice in the roar of guns. 

There are things to be done here, at home. A rot in the bones of our own land. Poverty, hunger, the slow decay of dreams. These are the battles that demand our attention. 

The money, the endless money, it's a river flowing into a bottomless pit. A pit built of sand and dust, of promises broken and lives extinguished. 

The time has come to turn away. To close the book on this chapter. To let the desert reclaim its own. The sons of that land must learn to fend for themselves. They must find their own path. 

It's time to walk away.

The question hung there, a fly caught in the amber of the air.  Someone, it seemed, had gone searching, peering into the digital dark. Found something.  Stopped it.  Was it wrong?  This invasion, this looking.  

On these Myspace things, you put things out there.  Information.  Open.  Like a town square, everyone walks by.  Friend or stranger, it's all the same.  You've given them leave to see, to read.   

But what if you're looking for something else?  Not just any profile.  Looking for the signs, the whispers, the darkness brewing beneath the surface.  One man watching them all.  The good and the bad.  Seems wrong somehow.  A violation.  But what if it saves a life?

It's a hard thing.  A thin line.  Information out there, open to the taking.  Like a river flowing, you can't dam it up.  But you can try to watch the currents, to know where the danger might lie.

I see it myself, the creeping shadows.  People looking in, knowing things they shouldn't.  My own picture, my words, my life, laid bare.  A man on TV, a ghoul.  He showed how easy it was.  Found a girl's name, her screen, her world.  Talked to her, tricked her, all in a whisper.  He knew her secrets before she even knew what was coming.

It's a strange feeling, this knowing.  That someone out there, a stranger, knows you better than you know yourself.  Your likes, your fears, your hopes.  It's a violation, a theft.

But it's also a part of this world now.  The internet, a vast and sprawling thing.  A place where secrets are whispered and shared, where the lines between public and private blur. 

The school, they tried to stop it.  Myspace banned.  A line drawn in the sand.  But can you really stop the flow?  Can you hold back the tide?

The desert wind scoured the edges of thought. This war. A stain on the sand. A bad idea from the start, they said. And they were right. The world knew it. Even those who wore the uniform, the ones sent to sift the sand for hope, knew it. A silent understanding in the eyes, a weariness in the heart. The polls, they spoke their truth.  Seventy-five percent, eighty percent. A chorus of dissent rising from the earth itself.  The Iraqi dust, the smoke of burning oil, the ghosts of a shattered land. It clung to the air, a constant reminder of the folly. Democracy, they said, a seed sown in barren ground. A fragile thing, crushed beneath the weight of history.  Saddam, a tyrant, yes. But what good is a fallen king if his kingdom crumbles to dust?  The desert waits, patient and unforgiving. It swallows the past, the present, the future. What good is staying? What hope is there in the wasteland?

The world, it ain't changed much. Not for women, anyway.  The glass ceiling, they call it.  Still there, though it's supposed to be shattered. Men, they got trouble seeing a woman at the head of the table. Like it ain't natural. Ain't right.  But you see it in every damn field.  

Take a woman with the know-how, the qualifications, she's ready to climb. But the men at the top, they don't take her serious. They see a woman, they think weakness. History, it's a heavy thing, drags us down.

Same for the men.  Tried to raise a child, stay home with the little ones?  They get the stink eye.  Society expects the man to be the provider, the breadwinner.  But what about the man who wants to nurture?  To hold his child, teach him, raise him?  He gets judged.  

And in those fancy places, the fashion world, the men who love it, they get looked at funny.  Don't belong there, they say.  Too feminine. Like a man can't know beauty, can't understand style.  

It's a twisted thing, this world we live in.  Change is slow, gradual like the setting sun. We're getting there, though.  More women in the boardrooms, more men at home with the kids.  It's a fight, but we're fighting.

They didn’t make it legal, no. Decriminalized it.  Knocked it down from a crime to a ticket.  Something you get cited for, not booked, not hauled in.  Still, the shadow of the charge, it lingers. Job interviews, all those things.  The weight of it, even with the label changed. 

Kids worry about that. The future, the mark it leaves.  But the state, they spend a fortune catching, holding, charging.  A court appearance here, maybe two, three.  Public defenders, judges, the whole apparatus.  And for what?  A lot of municipalities, strapped for coin, they can’t afford to let go of that revenue.  Even if it frees up funds for schools, for the elderly, for the hungry.

Denver’s different.  People there, they lean a different way.  Liberal, they call it.  More open.  And so maybe there, it makes sense.  The money saved, it can go elsewhere.

But to legalize it, to sell it like cigarettes,  that’s a different matter.  Everywhere, smoke curling from cars, from mouths on every street corner.  It wouldn’t feel right.  There’s a stigma, a taboo, that wouldn’t disappear that easy.

Alcohol, it’s worse for your hands, maybe.  But weed, it twists your life, your habits.  Both bad in their own ways.  But people, they react different.  Some go wild, some find balance.  It’s hard to say.

The Church. A house of stone and shadow. They say tradition is a root, that it holds you firm. But roots can strangle, too. They cling to the old ways, the dust on the altars, the pronouncements from long dead men. And they judge. They judge the straying sheep, the ones who don't fit the fold. My mother, she walked a different path. Episcopalian. They wouldn't let them in the church.  She loved God, but they wouldn't have her.  Love them, they preach. But this love is a cage, a gilded cage, for the chosen few. They speak of grace, but they offer only judgment.  

They say priests should be above it all,  above the weight of the flesh. But the flesh is a heavy thing.  It yearns. It betrays. And in the dark, behind closed doors, the sanctity of the cloth can’t hold back the shadows.  A man’s hunger, it knows no commandments.  They say marriage would be a distraction, but the heart seeks connection, even in the darkest of places. Is it the cloth that corrupts, or the man beneath? 

I don’t know.  I only know the stain of hypocrisy, the smell of incense masking the stench of rot.

The matter hangs heavy. No easy answers there. Right and wrong, a blurred line in the dust. This thing, the church and the state, tangled up with the very definition of a bond. A line walked on eggshells, lest we offend some corner of the world.  

Civil unions, maybe. A simple joining. Two souls. The government, should it concern itself with the particulars of such a thing?  Baptized souls, they walk unseen by the ledger of the state. The same should hold true for those bound in marriage. A sacrament, a joining of hearts, not a legal instrument to be weighed and measured.

But if the states can find common ground, a logic to the matter, then let it rise, a federal law.  But to amend the Constitution, to ban this love, this union, that is a folly. The Constitution, a heavy thing, not to be tampered with for matters of fleeting passions. Let them live their lives, these souls bound by love. Leave the Constitution to rest.

Raised in the fold. Christian. The word hangs, a shadow, over these matters.  Sexuality, a tangled vine, twisting in the light. Friends, some of them drawn towards the dark, the unspoken.  I don't know that I could walk that path myself. But the law, that's a different thing.  A heavy hand, reaching too far, dictating the lives of men.  The whole country, bound by a single decree?  No.  Let the states decide.  Let the people of each land choose their own way.  Some states lean left, some right.  The tide turns, the wind shifts.  Let them grapple with these questions, these choices.  A man can't choose his own home, but he can choose to abide by its laws.  Give them the same chance.  Equal footing.  Same as the rest.  Let the states decide.  And let the president, that distant hand, stay out of it. His power, it doesn't reach to every corner.

The boy spoke slow.  His words hung heavy in the air, like smoke from some long-dead fire. "It's public," he said. "Like a bulletin board. If you put something out there, you gotta figure folks'll see it.  School folks too."  He paused, fiddling with a loose thread on his shirt. 

"They weren't using the school's name or nothin'," he continued, "but they coulda found it. From their own homes.  Maybe it's wrong, maybe it ain't.  But if it stops some kid from gettin' hurt, well, that's a good thing, ain't it?  That's what schools are for. Keepin' folks safe."

He chewed on his lip, eyes fixed on the floor. "You know, it's easier to say what you mean when you're writin'.  But when you're talkin', words get tangled up, like weeds in a ditch." He looked up, his gaze direct. "Like I said, it's public. If you don't want folks seein' what you're sayin', you keep it to yourself."

He recalled a teacher, a woman with tired eyes and a voice worn thin from years of talkin' to kids. "She said, 'We gotta be safe,' she said. 'We gotta be ready for anything.'" He remembered the drills, the cold metal of the fire escape, the way the world seemed to shrink down to the size of that classroom. "We practiced, just in case.  Didn't want to be caught off guard."

He sighed, the weight of it all settling on his shoulders.  "That's what they were doin', I reckon. Just tryin' to keep folks safe. From somethin' bad."

The war. A fevered thing. Nine eleven. It burned in ya. Made ya want to answer back.  Like fire for fire.  Go over there and make them feel what we felt.  But maybe that was the sickness. All that heat. Didn't leave room for thinking.  No time for plans. Just fire. And it backfired.  It always does.

They fight amongst themselves.  Cannibal country.  Us going in there, it don't matter. They'll tear each other apart anyway. Doesn't change a thing.  I used to care, I guess. About what went on over there. Now it's just a weariness. A dull ache. Don't know if they're human anymore.  Just shadows with hatred in their eyes.

We went in blind. Didn't know what we faced. They fight different.  Savages.  Not building, not mending. Just tearing.  They want us gone. And maybe that's the only thing they're right about.  We shouldn't be there. Just hype.  Revenge.  Bush, he wanted it too. They wanted it. A voice in the dark saying "go." And we went.  

No thought. No plan. Just the echo of the fire.

transformed_texts:
The Church. It has its ways. Old ways. The men in robes talk of dwindling numbers. A harvest failing. I reckon it's these things they hold tight to, these rigid stances. Marriage, the taking of life, the control of the body. They speak of sin and damnation. But the world, it turns. Times change.

Folks don't bend so easy anymore. There's a restlessness out there, a hunger for something more. They see the Church, and they see a shadow. A darkness clinging to the corners of faith.

They say the Church is against abortion, against the joining of two souls in love, against the choices a woman makes. And some, they hear these words and walk away. They seek a different kind of sanctuary, one that doesn't judge, that doesn't condemn. 

A woman, a priestess, perhaps. A man, bound by vows but not to God alone.  These are the whispers in the wind. Could it have changed things? Maybe. But the darkness, it finds a way.

The matter of marriage.  A man and a woman. Two men. Two women.  Seems a simple enough thing, wouldn't you say? But the world, it twists and turns.  Some folks born a certain way. Some not. Doesn't make 'em any less...human.  To deny them the right, to call it wrong.  Seems a hard thing to stomach. Not my place to judge, not my choice to make. The government, they meddle in things they don't understand. This ain't a question of law, ain't no law against love, against the way folks feel.  It's about right and wrong.  And that's a question for the heart, not for some suit in Washington.

The matter of marriage, of two souls bound, is a thing the law should not hold in thrall. Some speak of threats, of the family structure warped by love between men or women. But what threat is there in devotion? In a world where shadows lengthen, where kinship is not always blood, is a love less true for lacking the shape prescribed?

The coin has two sides, yes. But it is the metal that matters, the heart that beats beneath. The law should not be a judge of the heart. There are rights, rights that bind, rights that shelter in sickness and in health. A partner denied, a hand held back, is a wound the law should not inflict.

And the studies whisper, a chorus of voices, that love finds its form in many ways. Happiness blooms in fields of every hue, in gardens cultivated by hands of different shapes.

The church, a house of faith, should not hold dominion over the state. Let the state provide shelter, let it not dictate the shape of love.

Some cling to ancient fears, to scriptures turned to iron bars. They speak of morality, of a path predestined. But morality is a shifting thing, a compass guided by the heart.

To deny a love, a bond forged in the fires of devotion, is to deny a part of the human story. It is to build walls where bridges should stand.  

It is in the embracing of difference, in the recognition of a love that knows no bounds, that we find the truest measure of humanity.

The pharmacy. Summer work. You see these pills, these poisons, stacked high behind glass.  Just because a thing is outlawed doesn't mean it holds no use.  No, sir.  There's a line.  For the open market, no.  But for healing?  Yes.  Medicinal, maybe.  Just because it's dirty doesn't mean it ain't got its uses.  

Think of the ones they keep locked tight, the oxycotins, the vicodins, the percocets.  Controlled, they call 'em.  But we dispense 'em daily.  For good, for bad.  Same with this weed. This marijuana.  They call it devil's lettuce, but it might just hold the key.  

Alcohol.  That's a different beast.  You can drown yourself in it, mind and body.  But this, this herb, it's different.  It ain't a demon, not like the hard stuff.  

Maybe a slow hand on the throttle.  Legalize it, yes, but not in a rush.  Let 'em get used to it, let the shame fade.  Then maybe, just maybe, they'll use it right.  

See, the fear they have... it's all made up.  They tell you it's poison, but it ain't heroin, ain't cocaine.  It's just a plant.  If you treat it with respect, maybe it'll give you back some.

The church, it’s changed. Like the wind shifts, it’s taken on a new shape. Not as stiff as it once was. I remember Sundays when I was a girl. Dresses all buttoned and laced. Shoes to match, a purse to match. Every Sunday, the ritual. Same as all the other girls. Private school, the whole lot of us, dressed up like dolls for mass. But now, it’s different. They’ve got a mass for the young ones, quick and sharp, thirty minutes gone in the blink of an eye. People come in their beach clothes, sand still clinging to their toes. Families rushing in late, children crying. Jeans and khakis now at the morning masses, where I used to stand stiff as a board in my Sunday best. 

The politics of it all, I don’t know much about that. But the change, I see it. That’s the church I know now.   

The talk, the accusations against the priests.  Evil things. I don’t know if any change could have stopped it. There are married men, good men, who do bad things. It’s a sickness, a darkness inside. Like a storm cloud gathering. It don't matter if they’re married or not.

They choose to be priests. It’s a path they walk. Some churches, they let the priests marry.  Like on that show, “Seventh Heaven.” The preacher, he had a wife, had children. But for those who choose the priesthood, maybe it’s not the right path. Maybe they should find a different way to serve.

This whole thing, it’s in their blood. It’s in their genes, I think.  Like a sickness passed down. Can’t hide it with a wedding ring.  It’d come out anyway.

If they knew and covered it up, shame on them. But maybe, in some cases, they didn’t know.

The laughter caught in his throat, a dry rasp. He'd tried to swallow it down, but the air itself felt thick with it. At first, he'd been okay, he supposed. But the day, that day, the world had tilted.  September's shadow had fallen long and heavy. And they went in, into that dust-filled land, under a guise, a pretense.  The Bush men, they'd tied it all together, the war, the towers, Bin Laden's shadow, Hussein's phantom weapons. A lie, all of it, a tapestry woven from smoke and fear.  It had chafed him, this deceit, this blood spilled in the name of a phantom enemy.  The Bush men, they'd lied to the people, plain and simple. Even Powell, the man who'd stood before the world and spun their tale, now admitted to doubt.  Malfeasance. An offense against the very heart of the nation.  

He saw it all, the slow erosion of the Constitution, the creeping darkness since the towers fell.  They'd come in, these men, with war in their eyes, a hunger for vengeance.  He recalled the name, a fleeting whisper, the treasury man who'd spoken truth, driven out like a dog.  The younger Bush, he'd carried the weight of his father's shadow, a thirst for retribution.  And oil. Always oil, the black blood whispering promises of power.

It had dragged on, this war, this wound festering in the land. A withdrawal, a sudden pullback, would only leave a bleeding corpse.  The UN, they'd spoken of a new order, a coalition, a patchwork of nations from the desert. But what guarantee was there?  Would Iraq's sovereignty be a hollow shell, a name whispered on the wind?

He saw the whispers, the news reports, the crumbling Parliament, the Prime Minister, a king without a kingdom.  Sadr, the man they'd fought, his name a ghost in the halls of power.  Factions, each clawing for control, each hungry for the spoils.  Friction, a slow burn, threatening to ignite the tinderbox. 

The laughter came again, this time a choked sound, swallowed back down. Words, they failed him.  There were things, truths, he couldn't speak, not in this light.

The air hung thick, hot.  The questions, they came like cicadas, buzzing in his ear.  Iraq. The word tasted like dust and ashes in his mouth.  A pointless thing, he thought. A reckoning, a score to settle.  But for what?  Ghosts of towers falling, a shadow cast across the world.  Nine-eleven.  A wound that wouldn't heal, festering.  He wasn't a soldier, never had been.  Didn't know the names of the battles, the faces of the lost.  Just knew the weight of it, the hollowness.  

Democracy, they said.  A seed planted in barren soil.  Oil, the black blood of the earth, a thirst that never quenched.  He saw the anger, the broken lives, the endless cycle of violence.  A land carved up, a people torn.  

To leave, to stay – both paths choked with thorns.  To fight, to build, to hold on.  The ghosts of Vietnam whispered in his ear, a warning.  A war without end, a stain on the nation's soul.  

He thought of the boys, the girls, the faces of the young, sent into the furnace.  And the families waiting, holding their breath, their hearts cracking.  He thought of the children, robbed of their laughter, their innocence.  A world drowned in blood, a future uncertain.  

The weight of it all, a burden too heavy to bear.  The war in Iraq, a tangled knot of shadows and lies.  No easy answers, only the echo of gunfire, the whisper of the wind through the ruins.

The law, it ain't right. No state should lay claim to it. This ain't their business. The Bible it speaks. Church and state. Divided. Plain as day. You try to force it, to twist it to your will, you're spitting in the face of what's already carved in stone.  The ones pushing it down, they're picking and choosing.  Favor one flock over another. The Catholics, most of 'em stand against it.  The Christians too.  Except up in Boston, maybe a few outposts. But the government, they got no right to tell the churches what they can and can't preach.  Separation. That's the heart of it.  Tolerance.  

To amend the thing, that's just wrong. A contradiction. The only amendment I can think of that would chain the people, not the government.

This ain't the government's fight.  This ain't about the economy or the streets. It's about faith, about personal convictions. The man pushing this, he's just trying to impose his own beliefs on the rest of us. One religion over all the others.

It belongs to the churches. It belongs to the people. Not the president, not the politicians.

The war. A long shadow. Iraq.  Didn't the government tell us the truth? About why they went in, why they claimed the desert was a battlefield.  A tangled web they spun, linking it to that September day, the smoke rising. But the desert held a different truth. A truth born of sand and blood. 

I've never been one for war.  Especially not this kind. A strike in the dark, preemptive. A gambler's bet with lives. Like Vietnam, a mirror held up, reflecting the ghosts of a past we refused to learn from. How many sons and daughters laid low, their dreams turned to dust?  And for what? To carve out a new order, to impose a government on a land that had a government of its own?  

They said they'd bring democracy. Like seeds sown in fertile ground. But the land was arid, its people hardened.  They fought not an army, but a spirit, a resistance born of grief and fear.  We thought it would be quick. A swift victory, a clean sweep.  But the desert doesn't yield easily. It swallows promises and spits out despair.

We've been there years now, still trying to mold the land to our will. Still teaching them to police themselves, to be the government we want them to be.  A long and bloody lesson, etched in the sand.  

Maybe we should have stayed away. Maybe we should have learned from the ghosts of Vietnam.  Maybe the truth wasn't hidden in the desert, but staring back at us from the mirror. A mirror reflecting our own hubris, our own thirst for dominion.

The boy spoke slow, drawling out the words like a hawk scanning the plains. "I'm for it," he said, "always have been." He squinted, as if the sun was too bright, or maybe he was just thinking hard. "A man loves a man, a woman a woman. It's a thing of the blood, not of the mind. To take that away, to deny them a name, a place at the table... that's a sin. It's inhuman." His voice dropped to a whisper. "My own street, there's a couple, two men, never married. They walk their dogs, like any other folks. They love each other. It's no different. But they can't say it, can't claim it." He spit on the ground. "That man in Washington, trying to play God, twisting the words of love... it's a mockery."

He paused, his eyes distant. "They say now, it's in the brain,  chemistry. Some things you're born with, can't help it. Like the sky, the rain, the pull of the earth." He sighed. "It ain't like a boy growing up with sisters, yearning for a brother. That ain't it." He shook his head. "It's a simple thing, love. Two people wanting to stay together, to build a life. Should be their own business, not the government's." 

He looked away, his voice a low rumble. "A man and a woman, they can run off, get hitched in Vegas. Nobody cares. But two men, two women... that's news. A scandal. It's wrong." He spat again, the sound sharp and metallic. "Love should be private, not a spectacle. It's not theirs to control."

The net. A public square. That's what they say. And it's true enough. You spit something out there, it hangs in the air. Colors folks' minds.  Might be harmless enough, a joke maybe. Or it might be a whisper of fire.  

Seen it myself.  As a resident advisor, you see the undercurrents.  A kid posts some talk about blowin' things up, about violence, and the whispers start. Someone's gotta hear it. Someone's gotta act.  They can't just let it float, can they? What if it takes root? What if it blossoms? 

But the line's blurry, ain't it?  Sometimes it's just kids, messing around.  A sociology project gone wrong, maybe. A bad joke, meant to be funny, but landing heavy as a tombstone.  

Then there are the times when it's not a joke.  A seed of darkness, planted in the fertile ground of the net.  A boy, a friend, something he posted. A dark joke, maybe. But in the right light, it looked like a threat. 

The school found out. Had to. It's a tightrope walk, between freedom and fear.  You put it out there, it's out there.  No privacy in the net.

The war. It stretches on. A wound that won't close. At first, it had a purpose, they said. Democracy for a land choked by tyrants. But the purpose, like the desert wind, has shifted. Now it's something else. A show of force. A hunger to prove dominion. Maybe the hunger was there all along. Bush the elder and his grudges with the desert fox. A serpent's coil tightening around a nation.  

If the aim had been to bring light to the darkness, to lift the weight of tyranny, that would have been a cause worthy of steel and blood. But if it was fueled by personal debts, by ghosts of battles past, then it was a sickness from the start.

The first strike, it spoke volumes. A thunderclap in the stillness. But the echo lingers. Years bleed into years. The desert sands turn red. And for what? We are the hammer, they say, but the anvil has moved too far.

A country cannot be built on the bones of men, nor on the spilled blood of boys. A nation doesn't find its voice in the roar of guns. 

There are things to be done here, at home. A rot in the bones of our own land. Poverty, hunger, the slow decay of dreams. These are the battles that demand our attention. 

The money, the endless money, it's a river flowing into a bottomless pit. A pit built of sand and dust, of promises broken and lives extinguished. 

The time has come to turn away. To close the book on this chapter. To let the desert reclaim its own. The sons of that land must learn to fend for themselves. They must find their own path. 

It's time to walk away.

The question hung there, a fly caught in the amber of the air.  Someone, it seemed, had gone searching, peering into the digital dark. Found something.  Stopped it.  Was it wrong?  This invasion, this looking.  

On these Myspace things, you put things out there.  Information.  Open.  Like a town square, everyone walks by.  Friend or stranger, it's all the same.  You've given them leave to see, to read.   

But what if you're looking for something else?  Not just any profile.  Looking for the signs, the whispers, the darkness brewing beneath the surface.  One man watching them all.  The good and the bad.  Seems wrong somehow.  A violation.  But what if it saves a life?

It's a hard thing.  A thin line.  Information out there, open to the taking.  Like a river flowing, you can't dam it up.  But you can try to watch the currents, to know where the danger might lie.

I see it myself, the creeping shadows.  People looking in, knowing things they shouldn't.  My own picture, my words, my life, laid bare.  A man on TV, a ghoul.  He showed how easy it was.  Found a girl's name, her screen, her world.  Talked to her, tricked her, all in a whisper.  He knew her secrets before she even knew what was coming.

It's a strange feeling, this knowing.  That someone out there, a stranger, knows you better than you know yourself.  Your likes, your fears, your hopes.  It's a violation, a theft.

But it's also a part of this world now.  The internet, a vast and sprawling thing.  A place where secrets are whispered and shared, where the lines between public and private blur. 

The school, they tried to stop it.  Myspace banned.  A line drawn in the sand.  But can you really stop the flow?  Can you hold back the tide?

The desert wind scoured the edges of thought. This war. A stain on the sand. A bad idea from the start, they said. And they were right. The world knew it. Even those who wore the uniform, the ones sent to sift the sand for hope, knew it. A silent understanding in the eyes, a weariness in the heart. The polls, they spoke their truth.  Seventy-five percent, eighty percent. A chorus of dissent rising from the earth itself.  The Iraqi dust, the smoke of burning oil, the ghosts of a shattered land. It clung to the air, a constant reminder of the folly. Democracy, they said, a seed sown in barren ground. A fragile thing, crushed beneath the weight of history.  Saddam, a tyrant, yes. But what good is a fallen king if his kingdom crumbles to dust?  The desert waits, patient and unforgiving. It swallows the past, the present, the future. What good is staying? What hope is there in the wasteland?

The world, it ain't changed much. Not for women, anyway.  The glass ceiling, they call it.  Still there, though it's supposed to be shattered. Men, they got trouble seeing a woman at the head of the table. Like it ain't natural. Ain't right.  But you see it in every damn field.  

Take a woman with the know-how, the qualifications, she's ready to climb. But the men at the top, they don't take her serious. They see a woman, they think weakness. History, it's a heavy thing, drags us down.

Same for the men.  Tried to raise a child, stay home with the little ones?  They get the stink eye.  Society expects the man to be the provider, the breadwinner.  But what about the man who wants to nurture?  To hold his child, teach him, raise him?  He gets judged.  

And in those fancy places, the fashion world, the men who love it, they get looked at funny.  Don't belong there, they say.  Too feminine. Like a man can't know beauty, can't understand style.  

It's a twisted thing, this world we live in.  Change is slow, gradual like the setting sun. We're getting there, though.  More women in the boardrooms, more men at home with the kids.  It's a fight, but we're fighting.

They didn’t make it legal, no. Decriminalized it.  Knocked it down from a crime to a ticket.  Something you get cited for, not booked, not hauled in.  Still, the shadow of the charge, it lingers. Job interviews, all those things.  The weight of it, even with the label changed. 

Kids worry about that. The future, the mark it leaves.  But the state, they spend a fortune catching, holding, charging.  A court appearance here, maybe two, three.  Public defenders, judges, the whole apparatus.  And for what?  A lot of municipalities, strapped for coin, they can’t afford to let go of that revenue.  Even if it frees up funds for schools, for the elderly, for the hungry.

Denver’s different.  People there, they lean a different way.  Liberal, they call it.  More open.  And so maybe there, it makes sense.  The money saved, it can go elsewhere.

But to legalize it, to sell it like cigarettes,  that’s a different matter.  Everywhere, smoke curling from cars, from mouths on every street corner.  It wouldn’t feel right.  There’s a stigma, a taboo, that wouldn’t disappear that easy.

Alcohol, it’s worse for your hands, maybe.  But weed, it twists your life, your habits.  Both bad in their own ways.  But people, they react different.  Some go wild, some find balance.  It’s hard to say.

The Church. A house of stone and shadow. They say tradition is a root, that it holds you firm. But roots can strangle, too. They cling to the old ways, the dust on the altars, the pronouncements from long dead men. And they judge. They judge the straying sheep, the ones who don't fit the fold. My mother, she walked a different path. Episcopalian. They wouldn't let them in the church.  She loved God, but they wouldn't have her.  Love them, they preach. But this love is a cage, a gilded cage, for the chosen few. They speak of grace, but they offer only judgment.  

They say priests should be above it all,  above the weight of the flesh. But the flesh is a heavy thing.  It yearns. It betrays. And in the dark, behind closed doors, the sanctity of the cloth can’t hold back the shadows.  A man’s hunger, it knows no commandments.  They say marriage would be a distraction, but the heart seeks connection, even in the darkest of places. Is it the cloth that corrupts, or the man beneath? 

I don’t know.  I only know the stain of hypocrisy, the smell of incense masking the stench of rot.

The matter hangs heavy. No easy answers there. Right and wrong, a blurred line in the dust. This thing, the church and the state, tangled up with the very definition of a bond. A line walked on eggshells, lest we offend some corner of the world.  

Civil unions, maybe. A simple joining. Two souls. The government, should it concern itself with the particulars of such a thing?  Baptized souls, they walk unseen by the ledger of the state. The same should hold true for those bound in marriage. A sacrament, a joining of hearts, not a legal instrument to be weighed and measured.

But if the states can find common ground, a logic to the matter, then let it rise, a federal law.  But to amend the Constitution, to ban this love, this union, that is a folly. The Constitution, a heavy thing, not to be tampered with for matters of fleeting passions. Let them live their lives, these souls bound by love. Leave the Constitution to rest.

Raised in the fold. Christian. The word hangs, a shadow, over these matters.  Sexuality, a tangled vine, twisting in the light. Friends, some of them drawn towards the dark, the unspoken.  I don't know that I could walk that path myself. But the law, that's a different thing.  A heavy hand, reaching too far, dictating the lives of men.  The whole country, bound by a single decree?  No.  Let the states decide.  Let the people of each land choose their own way.  Some states lean left, some right.  The tide turns, the wind shifts.  Let them grapple with these questions, these choices.  A man can't choose his own home, but he can choose to abide by its laws.  Give them the same chance.  Equal footing.  Same as the rest.  Let the states decide.  And let the president, that distant hand, stay out of it. His power, it doesn't reach to every corner.

The boy spoke slow.  His words hung heavy in the air, like smoke from some long-dead fire. "It's public," he said. "Like a bulletin board. If you put something out there, you gotta figure folks'll see it.  School folks too."  He paused, fiddling with a loose thread on his shirt. 

"They weren't using the school's name or nothin'," he continued, "but they coulda found it. From their own homes.  Maybe it's wrong, maybe it ain't.  But if it stops some kid from gettin' hurt, well, that's a good thing, ain't it?  That's what schools are for. Keepin' folks safe."

He chewed on his lip, eyes fixed on the floor. "You know, it's easier to say what you mean when you're writin'.  But when you're talkin', words get tangled up, like weeds in a ditch." He looked up, his gaze direct. "Like I said, it's public. If you don't want folks seein' what you're sayin', you keep it to yourself."

He recalled a teacher, a woman with tired eyes and a voice worn thin from years of talkin' to kids. "She said, 'We gotta be safe,' she said. 'We gotta be ready for anything.'" He remembered the drills, the cold metal of the fire escape, the way the world seemed to shrink down to the size of that classroom. "We practiced, just in case.  Didn't want to be caught off guard."

He sighed, the weight of it all settling on his shoulders.  "That's what they were doin', I reckon. Just tryin' to keep folks safe. From somethin' bad."

The war. A fevered thing. Nine eleven. It burned in ya. Made ya want to answer back.  Like fire for fire.  Go over there and make them feel what we felt.  But maybe that was the sickness. All that heat. Didn't leave room for thinking.  No time for plans. Just fire. And it backfired.  It always does.

They fight amongst themselves.  Cannibal country.  Us going in there, it don't matter. They'll tear each other apart anyway. Doesn't change a thing.  I used to care, I guess. About what went on over there. Now it's just a weariness. A dull ache. Don't know if they're human anymore.  Just shadows with hatred in their eyes.

We went in blind. Didn't know what we faced. They fight different.  Savages.  Not building, not mending. Just tearing.  They want us gone. And maybe that's the only thing they're right about.  We shouldn't be there. Just hype.  Revenge.  Bush, he wanted it too. They wanted it. A voice in the dark saying "go." And we went.  

No thought. No plan. Just the echo of the fire.
